_chemical.ChemicalName: Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2021 General Executive Summary for The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations Site.





Revisions to the Plan



Revisions to the July 9th, 2019 plan are being submitted on July 1st, 2021 for the following reasons:



Separation of The Dow Chemical Company and Hemlock Semiconductor plans:

The Dow Chemical Company ("Dow") completed a divestiture of a portion of the Trichlorosilane process.  This process will be included in the risk management plan of Hemlock Semiconductor. 

Process Boundary and Maximum Inventory Verification

The 32 Incinerator process has verified its RMP chemical coverage, process boundaries, maximum intended inventories, as well as implemented the mixture rules set forth in the RMP rule rather than using the more conservative approach employed in the past. Inventories and boundaries in the Chlorosilane Production process were verified to remove Hemlock Semiconductor assets from the Dow plan. A number of the scenarios were updated in the Chlorosilanes process in order to maintain consistency across the interconnected programs.  The 588 Process was removed from the plan due to being interconnected to an i-park tenant and as a result below the threshold for chlorine. 

Removal of Regulated Substances:

Chlorine was removed from the plan due to no longer exceeding threshold quantity in the 588 process. 

Ethylene was removed from the 32 Incinerator process as it has been verified to be below 1%. 

Addition of Regulated Substances: 

The 32 Incinerator process added two regulated substances as part of the chemical review. 



?    Trichlorosilane

?    Vinyl ethyl ether



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Michigan Operations site is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at

the facility.  Appropriate controls are implemented to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release were to occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  The facility also coordinates with the LEPC and City of Midland Fire Department which can provide additional emergency response expertise.





Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Dow Chemical Company Michigan Operations site operates under two air permits. There is insufficient room in the registration section to list this information for both companies there, so we are providing the information on the second air permit here. The air operating permit for the Dow Silicones Corporation (formerly known as Dow Corning) portion of the stationary source is ROP-A4043-2008.  The DUNS for Dow Silicones Corporation is 005353487.  

The Michigan Operations site's primary activity is chemical manufacturing, including specialty chemicals, silicones and plastics.  There are twenty-five (25) covered processes, forty (40) programs and thirty-one (31) regulated substances present at the stationary source.  



The regulated substances are listed below.  Six (6) of the chemicals in the list are not routinely stored on site and/or if present, are present in less than threshold amounts and have been added under the provision of predictive filing.  Predictive filing was done for flammable or toxic chemicals which may be included in waste mixtures received at the facility.



Regulated Substances:



1, 3-Butadiene

2-Methylpropene [1-Propene, 2-methyl-]

Acetaldehyde

Acrylonitrile [predictive]

Ammonia (Anhydrous)

Ammonia (conc 20% or greater)

Boron Trichloride

Butene

Dichlorosilane

Dimethyldichlorosilane 

Epichlorohydrin (2-chloromethyl oxirane) [predictive]

Ethyl chloride

Ethyl Ether (di ethyl ether)

Ethylene

Ethylenediamine

Hydrogen chloride (anhydrous)

Isopentane

Isopropyl chloride

Meth

yl chloride

Methyl ether

Methyltrichlorosilane 

Pentane [predictive]

Propylene

Propylene oxide

Tetramethylsilane

Trichlorosilane

Trimethylchlorosilane 

Vinyl acetate monomer [predictive]

Vinyl ethyl ether

Vinylidene chloride









Worst and Alternative Case Scenario Selection



Where worst and alternate case scenarios impacted additional receptors, all scenarios were included in the submittal. There are six (6) worst case toxic and four (4) worst case flammable scenarios in this submittal. There are nineteen (15) total alternate cases, one (1) of which is a flammable case. 



One item to note is that Rail Waldo Yard 2-methylpropene flammable worst case is included as impacting a population of eighty-six (86) due to a Google Earth verification depicting approximately 40 housing units. A population density of 2.15 per housing unit was utilized to arrive at the estimated population. Marplot showed this scenario as having zero population and housing unit impacts. 







The General Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Michigan Operations site has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  Several processes at the facility are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard under 19 CFR 1910.119.  The facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the Michigan Operations Site.





Process Safety Information



The Michigan Operations site maintains detailed records of safety information that, among other things, describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment design associated with all covered processes.  Numerous types of information are available to supplement safety information, including Safety Data Sheets for materials used on site, equipment and engineering design specifications and applicable

reactive chemicals testing.



Process Hazard Analysis



The Michigan Operations site conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  For initial screening and risk evaluation, calculations of Fire and Explosion and Chemical Exposure Indices are performed, and a Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analysis is conducted.  These methodologies are supplemented when needed with analyses that may include:  What if Analysis, Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), Fault Tree Analysis and Safer Technology and Alternative Analysis (STAA).  A team of qualified personnel performs the studies along with experts in engineering and process operations.  



Operating Procedures



For the purpose of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, the Michigan Operations site maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.



Training



The Michigan Operations site has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity



The Michigan Operations site carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training

in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel receive specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change



Written procedures are in place at the Michigan Operations site to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training on the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews



Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of existing processes are conducted as a regular practice at the Michigan Operations Site.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating & maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup, and that all necessary personnel have been trained prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits



The Michigan Operations site conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule and other applicable regulatory requirements are being followed and have been implemented properly.  Audits are conducted using an established schedule for the site.  Corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



Incident Investigation



The Michigan Operations site promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a serious release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the root causes leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring.  



Employee Participation



The Michigan Operations site operates on the premise that process safety management and accident prevention are a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident pr

evention issues, to attend applicable reviews, and to recommend improvements.  Improvements are solicited and implemented as appropriate.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.



Contractors



On occasion, the Michigan Operations site hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  The facility has a strict program for informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes, as well as the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Contractors are also required to inform the facility of any hazards they may introduce or encounter while at the site.



Five-year Accident History



The Michigan Operations site has not had any accidents to report as part of the RMP.   



Emergency Response Plan



The Michigan Operations site maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan documents all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The plan is updated as necessary to reflect any pertinent changes within the processes at the facility that would require a modified emergency response.



The facility works with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the facility emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.



Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced in order to ensure that it is functioning properly at all times.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Michigan Operations is improvin

g internal reporting and investigation of small process safety incidents in order to raise awareness and take corrective actions to prevent larger incidents. We are implementing significant personnel training improvements, increased equipment inspections, and implementing projects to strengthen our layers of protection against process safety incidents. The Michigan Operations Site also works with the Department of Homeland Security to ensure full compliance with the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard.
